results.title: Dead Heart (A) (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Constable Ray Lorkin (Bryan Brown) struggles to maintain law and order in the Aboriginal community of Wala Wala. The geographical isolation of the community is heightened by the incompatability between “white man’s justice” and indigenous tribal law. The situation reaches crisis point when a young Aboriginal (Aaron Pedersen) allows the white woman with whom he is having an affair to view a sacred initiation site. “Dead Heart” presents an honest portrayal of the conflict between two cultures and laws and the consequences that can occur. Parsons also wrote the script.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick Parsons, Helen Watts, Bryan Brown and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: Dead End Drive-in (AFC)
results.creator_credit: Brian Trenchard-Smith, A Williams, New South Wales Film Corporation and Springvale Productions
results.brief_description: Futuristic satirical comedy which revolves around the use of drive-in theatres as internment camps for outcasts from society where the unemployed and weak are fed junk food, music and bad films. When the film’s main character finds himself there by accident, he is obsessed by a desire to escape and find a new sense of purpose in his life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Trenchard-Smith, A Williams, New South Wales Film Corporation and Springvale Productions

results.title: Dead end
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Samuel Goldwyn and Samuel Goldwyn Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Sidney Kingsley play and scripted for the screen by Lillian Hellman, “Dead end” is one of the most acclaimed crime films. William Wyler directs the young cast of the Dead End Kids in this film which looks at the New York East Side as a breeding ground for potential criminals. Bogart plays gangster “Baby Face Martin”, Joel McCrae is Dave, the student architect trying to break free. America in the Depression is vividly portrayed and while the message of the film is less than subtle, the performances are excellent, as is the script. Co-starring Sylvia Sidney as the sensitive, caring sister of one of the boys.

results.title: Dead easy
results.creator_credit: Bert Deling, John Weiley and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: Set in Sydney and supposedly based on actual events, a policeman, prostitute and a hustler become involved in gang war and find that life can be very dangerous. After they cross a small-time bookie they are hunted by every hoodlum in town.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Deling, John Weiley and Firebird Films

results.title: Dead calm
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, George Miller, Doug Mitchell, Terry Hayes, Warner Bros Pictures and Kennedy Miller Productions
results.brief_description: A psychothriller from the novel by Charles Williams about a married couple who have taken time out to recover from a family tragedy by spending time on their yacht at sea. This seemingly idyllic break soon turns into a nightmare when the couple rescue a young man from a drifting boat, unaware of the stranger’s violent and sociopathic personality that is about to set upon them. Stars Sam Neill, Nicole Kidman, Billy Zane. Cinematography by Dean Semler.

results.title: Dead birds
results.brief_description: An interpretation of the life and customs of the Dani people of Central West Irian, who exist in continuous warfare between neighbouring villages, reduced to ritualised alternating attacks. Robert Gardner’s study of the life and customs of the Baliem Valley people of western New Guinea. Explores the nature of primitive warfare and its motivations. Shows traditional mutilation and death customs as well as food production, housing, mythology, clothing, ornament, and art.

results.title: De Renoir a Picasso
results.creator_credit: Paul Haesaerts and Jean Van Raemdonck
results.brief_description: Part of the “Art et cinema” series, this film presents a study and comparison of the characteristics of Renoir the sensualist, Seurat, the intellectual, and Picasso, the instructive artist, the three main inspirational sources for modern French art. The soft, rounded forms of Renoir are related to the Greek ideal of physical beauty, Seurat’s severe simplification are shown to echo Byzantine style; and Picasso’s distortions are traced back to similar experiments in primitive art.

results.title: De Munich a la Drole de Guerre (1938-1939) Pt. 06
results.brief_description:
Part 6 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. At the end of the tumultuous 1930s, French cinema produces the full range of film genre: film noir, film rose, comedies. During the decade, Renoir and Carne will produce their best work. Julien Duvivier directs ‘Carnet de bal’, followed by ‘La fin du jour’ and ‘La charette fantome’. Some directors experience difficulties to impose subjects which are not pure entertainement. Nevertheless, Marc Allegret is allowed to to do ‘Razumoff’, a film dealing with Russian revolutionaries. In ‘Gribouille’, Allegret casts a promising young actress, Michele Morgan. During this decade, a long list of young actors are given their first chance to appear in the big screen. Some of them will go on to become iconic figures of French cinema for fourty years and more. Young hopefuls such as Claude Dauphin, Bernard Blier, Odette Joyeux play young hopeful actors auditioning for the ‘Conservatoire’ in front of Louis Jouvet, playing himself in ‘Entree des artistes’. Jean Gremillon, with the support of Raoul Ploquin, is filming ‘L’etrange Mr. Victor’ in Berlin for the French section of UFA. Based in Paris, G.W. Pabst directs ‘Le drame de Shanghai’ and ‘Damsel in distress’. During the last years of the 1930s Pagnol directs ‘Regain’ and ‘La femme du boulanger’. Theatre man Sacha Guitry learns the craft of filmmaking and makes a specialty of adapting his plays and creating historical dramas with 1000s of cameo apparitions. In spite of many attempts to resurface, pioneers such as Gance and L’Herbier are not able to renew with box-office success. A lesser known figure of the period is Pierre Chenal. He made a German expressionist-style Dostoyevsky adaptation, ‘Crime and Punishment’ (1935) in which he used set design, lighting, a breathtakingly mobile camera, and voice-over monologues to evoke a tormented consciousness at the breaking point. In adapting James M. Cain’s ‘The postman alway rings twice’ as ‘Le dernier tournant’ (1939), he shot extensively on location, in another French adumbration (along with Renoir’s ‘Toni’ (1934) and most of Pagnol’s work) of postwar Neorealism. In ‘L’alibi’ (1938), which stylistically and thematically is the closest of his films to the work of Carne and Prevert, he all but abandoned his usual moving camera, while multiplying (studio shot) expressionistic effects of lighting and composition.” Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992. * Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Interviewees include: Yves Allegret, Marc Allegret, Charles Spaak, Marcel Pagnol, Francoise Giroud, Henri-George Clouzot.

results.title: De Mayerling a Sarajevo = from Mayerling to Sarajevo
results.brief_description:
Ophuls traces the fall of the Austro-Hungarian empire by spiritually linking the tragic 19th century romance of Crown Duke Rudolph and Baroness Maria Vetsera to the 1914 assassination of Archduke Ferdinand and the subsequent outbreak of WWI. Mistrusted by his aristocratic peers because of his progressively democratic notions, Ferdinand seems destined to be martyred at the hands of his enemies, in much the same way that Rudolph was.

Credits: Producer, Eugene Tucherer ; director, Max Ophuls ; writers, Marcelle Maurette, Carl Zuckmayer, Jacques Natanson, Andre-Paul Antoine ; photography, Curt Alexandre, Curt Courant, Otto Heller ; music, Oscar Straus ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonn
Cast: Edwige Feuillere, Gabrielle Doziat, John Lodge, Jacqueline Marsan, Aime Clariond, Monique Clariond, Jean Worms, Colette Regis, Jean Debucourt, Raymond Aimos, Henri Bosc.
